item.title: Gulp dotnet tasks
item.description: Not sure if this will help anyway, but running dnu and dnx tasks (soon to be aggregated under a single ‘dotnet’) is really easy.

item.title: Review: Microsoft .NET – Architecting Applications for the Enterprise, 2nd Edition
item.description: I’ve recently finished reading Microsoft .NET – Architecting Applications for the Enterprise, 2nd Edition by Dino Esposito and Andrea Saltarello. This book caught my attention for two reasons.

item.title: Software Abstractions take Skill.
item.description: I recently read Adaptive Code via C# and posted a review on Amazon: This book is a new favorite of mine.

item.title: ASP.NET, AppDomains, and shadow-copying
item.description:
I answered a question on StackOverflow nearly two years ago, and I’m surprised at how few votes it has received, despite comments such as:

+1 for teaching me something new today thanks. -kobe

Being one of my favorite answers, I thought I should discuss it on my blog a little more in-depth than just posting the SO answer. I’d like to briefly discuss what ASP.NET really is (in the context of IIS), why AppDomains are needed, and lastly what shadow-copying does for an application. There is no code associated with this post, and it is driven more by contemplation than by a specific resolution to a problem. So, I apologize in advance if it seems disjointed at times.

item.title: ASP.NET BuildResultCompiledAssembly error
item.description: Unable to cast object of type ‘System.Web.Compilation.BuildResultCompiledAssembly’ to type ‘System.Web.Compilation.BuildResultCompiledGlobalAsaxType’. This has been reported as a bug. But there is no solution.

item.title: DataAnnotations, MVC 3, and Unobtrusive Validations
item.description:
DataAnnotations are a pretty cool introduction to .NET 3.5+. It is very useful in ASP.NET MVC 3, and I’ve written a somewhat naive attempt to use this functionality in ASP.NET Web Forms which some people have found very useful.

I’d like to dig a little more in depth…

item.title: What happens when I overwrite a DLL (asp.net)?
item.description:
I post on Stack Overflow a lot. Sometimes, there are really interesting questions like one I answered last year. I had forgotten about it until this week when the answer was accepted. I thought I’d share it on my blog.

The original post is here. Read on for redundancy.

item.title: NHibernate.Criterion Extensions workaround
item.description: I’ve been working with Fluent NHibernate for the past month or so, and I realized while writing an NHibernate query that the NHibernate Criterion’s Restrictions class isn’t very refactor-friendly.

item.title: IHttpModule Gotchas @dominicpettifer.co.uk
item.description: I came across this blog post about the Init() method of an HttpModule being called more than once. The solution is simple: create a boolean flag to indicate whether or not the app is started and an empty object to lock.

item.title: log4net configuration in .NET 3.5
item.description: Step 1 Add Reference Right click on the “References” folder and choose add reference. Browse to the location of log4net and add it to the project.

item.title: Quickly create a Dictionary using Linq to Objects
item.description: When working with collections or lists, sometimes you just need to get a simple dictionary. There are a number of ways to do this, but the ToDictionary method seems promising.

item.title: UpdatePanel won’t AsycPostback for anything.
item.description: I spent a lot of time today and Friday trying to get my UpdatePanel to be handled properly. No matter what I did, my asynchronous triggers were only posting back.

item.title: jQuery check/uncheck all Checkboxes in ASP.NET
item.description: For some odd reason, ASP.NET GridView wraps html elements in a span element. When you apply a CssClass to the asp:CheckBox for instance, you will have a span with that class and inside you’ll have an input with type=checkbox.

item.title: Storing Generics in ASP.NET Profile object
item.description: Sometimes, I’ll come across a problem that I research for an hour or two. When I find the solution, I think “Wow, that should have been the first thing I tried!
